page.title: 14HOMELIFE
page.content: In Kingston, Bishopsbourne and the immediate surrounding areas, there is mains drainage but septic tanks are still used in the isolated dwellings. Refuse is collected weekly. Telephones and electricity are available to all, but mains gas only reaches the two villages. Practically all homes would have hot and cold water and bathroom. The newer houses, and those which have been modernised, have central heating, using either gas, electricity, oil or solid fuel. Most households contain the more usual electrical appliances, e.g. vacuum cleaner, washing machine, iron, hairdryer and refrigerator. Deep freezers prove particularly useful in rural areas. Less common were dish- washers, tumbler dryers and micro-wave ovens. T.V. and/or radio appear in all homes, and vidoe recordering machines are gaining in popularity.
